3.text: Organic Chemicals

1668.text: 1. Except where the context otherwise requires, the headings of this Chapter apply only to:

contains.0: (a) Separate chemically defined organic compounds, whether or not containing impurities;
contains.1: (b) Mixtures of two or more isomers of the same organic compound (whether or not containing impurities), except mixtures of acyclic hydrocarbon isomers (other than stereoisomers), whether or not saturated (Chapter 27);
contains.2: (c) The products of headings 2936 to 2939 or the sugar ethers, sugar acetals and sugar esters, and their salts, of heading 2940, or the products of heading 2941, whether or not chemically defined;
contains.3: (d) The products mentioned in (a), (b) or (c) above dissolved in water;
contains.4: (e) The products mentioned in (a), (b), or (c) above dissolved in other solvents provided that the solution constitutes a normal and necessary method of putting up these products adopted solely for reasons of safety or for transport and that the solvent does not render the product particularly suitable for specific use rather than for general use;
contains.5: (f) The products mentioned in (a), (b), (c), (d) or (e) above with an added stabiliser (including an anti- caking agent) necessary for their preservation or transport;
contains.6: (g) The products mentioned in (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f) above with an added anti-dusting agent or a colouring or odoriferous substance added to facilitate their identification or for safety reasons, provided that the additions do not render the product particularly suitable for specific use rather than for general use;
contains.7: (h) The following products, diluted to standard strengths, for the production of azo dyes: diazonium salts, couplers used for these salts and diazotisable amines and their salts.

8.text: 2. This Chapter does not cover:

contains.0: (a) Goods of heading 1504 or crude glycerol of heading 1520;
contains.2: (c) Methane or propane (heading 2711);
contains.3: (d) The compounds of carbon mentioned in Note 2 to Chapter 28;
contains.4: 1[(e) Immunological products of heading 3002]
contains.5: 2[(f) Urea (heading 3102 or 3105);
contains.6: (g) Colouring matter of vegetable or animal origin (heading 3203), synthetic organic colouring matter, synthetic organic products of a kind used as fluorescent brightening agents or as luminophores (heading 3204) or dyes or other colouring matter put up in forms or packings for retail sale (heading 3212);
contains.7: (h) Enzymes (heading 3507);
contains.8: (ij) Metaldehyde, hexamethylenetetramine or similar substances, put up in forms (for example, tablets, sticks or similar forms) for use as fuels, or liquid or liquefied-gas fuels in containers of a kind used for filling or refilling cigarette or similar lighters and of a capacity not exceeding 300 cm3(heading 3606);
contains.9: (k) Products put up as charges for fire-extinguishers or put up in fire-extinguishing grenades, of heading 3813; ink removers put up in packings for retail sale, of heading 3824; or
contains.10: (l) Optical elements, for example, of ethylenediamine tartrate (heading 9001).]

contains.9: 3. Goods which could be included in two or more of the headings of this Chapter are to be classified in that one of those headings which occurs last in numerical order.
contains.10: 4. In headings 2904 to 2906, 2908 to 2911 and 2913 to 2920, any reference to halogenated, sulphonated, nitrated or nitrosated derivatives includes a reference to compound derivatives, such as sulphohalogenated, nitrohalogenated, nitrosulphonated or nitrosulphohalogenated derivatives.
contains.11: Nitro or nitroso groups are not to be taken as “nitrogen-functions” for the purposes of heading 2929.
contains.12: For the purposes of headings 2911, 2912, 2914, 2918 and 2922, “oxygen-function” is to be restricted to the functions (the characteristic organic oxygen-containing groups) referred to in headings 2905 to 2920.
contains.13: 5. 1[(A)] The esters of acid-function organic compounds of Sub-Chapters I to VII with organic compounds of these Sub-Chapters are to be classified with that compound which is classified in the heading which occurs last in numerical order in these Sub-Chapters.
contains.14: 1[(B)] Esters of ethyl alcohol with acid-function organic compounds of Sub-Chapters I to VII are to be classified in the same heading as the corresponding acid-function compounds.

15.text: 1[(C)] Subject to Note 1 to Section VI and Note 2 to Chapter 28:

contains.0: 2[(1)] Inorganic salts of organic compounds such as acid-, phenol- or enol-function compounds or organic bases, of Sub-Chapters I to X or heading 2942, are to be classified in the heading appropriate to the organic 3[compound;]
contains.1: 2[(2)] Salts formed between organic compounds of Sub-Chapters I to X or heading 2942 are to be classified in the heading appropriate to the base or to the acid (including phenol-or enol-function compounds) from which they are formed, whichever occurs last in numerical order in the Chapter.
contains.2: 1[(3) co-ordination compounds, other than products classifiable in Sub-Chapter XI or heading 2941, are to be classified in the heading which occurs last in numerical order in Chapter 29, among those appropriate to the fragments formed by “cleaving” of all metal bonds, other than metal-carbon bonds.]
contains.3: 2[(D)] Metal alcoholates are to be classified in the same heading as the corresponding alcohols except in the case of ethanol (heading 2905).
contains.4: 2[(E)] Halides of carboxylic acids are to be classified in the same heading as the corresponding acids.

contains.16: 6. The compounds of headings 2930 and 2931 are organic compounds the molecules of which contain, in addition to atoms of hydrogen, oxygen or nitrogen, atoms of other non-metals or of metals (such as sulphur, arsenic, 3*** or lead) directly linked to carbon atoms.
contains.17: Heading 2930 (organo-sulphur compounds) and heading 2931 (other organo-inorganic compounds) do not include sulphonated or halogenated derivatives (including compound derivatives) which, apart from hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, only have directly linked to carbon the atoms of sulphur or of a halogen which give them their nature of sulphonated or halogenated derivatives (or compound derivatives).
contains.18: 7. Headings 2932, 2933 and 2934 do not include epoxides with a three- membered ring, ketone peroxides, cyclic polymers of aldehydes or of 4[thioaldehydes, anhydrides] of polybasic carboxylic acids, cyclic esters of polyhydric alcohols or phenols with polybasic acids, or imides of polybasic acids.
contains.19: These provisions apply only when the ring-position hetero-atoms are those resulting solely from the cyclising function or functions here listed.

contains.0: (a) the term “hormones” includes hormone-releasing or hormone-stimulating factors, hormone inhibitors and hormone antagonists (anti-hormones);

1.text: (b) the expression “used primarily as hormones” applies not only to hormone derivatives and structural analogues used primarily for their hormonal effect, but also to those derivatives and structural analogues used primarily as intermediates in the synthesis of products of this heading.

contains.21: 1.Within any one heading of this Chapter, derivatives of a chemical compound (or group of chemical compounds) are to be classified in the same sub-heading as that compound (or group of compounds) provided that they are not more specially covered by any other sub-heading and that there is no residual sub-heading named “other” in the series of subheadings concerned.
contains.22: 2. Note 3 to this Chapter shall not be applicable to the sub-headings of this Chapter.]

1.text: Soap, Organic Surface-Active Agents, Washing Preparations, Lubricating Preparations, Artificial Waxes, Prepared Waxes, Polishing or Scouring Preparations, Candles and Similar Articles, Modelling Pastes, “Dental Waxes” and Dental Preparations with a Basis of Plaster
1. This Chapter does not cover:

contains.0: (a) Edible mixtures or preparations of animal or vegetable fats or oils of a kind used as mould release preparations (heading 1517);
contains.2: (c) Shampoos, dentifrices, shaving creams and foams, or bath preparations, containing soap or other organic surface-active agents (heading 3305, 3306 or 3307.).

2. For the purposes of heading 3401, the expression “soap” applies only to soap soluble in water. Soap and the other products of heading 3401 may contain added substances (for example, disinfectants, abrasive powders, fillers or medicaments). Products containing abrasive powders remain classified in heading 3401 only if in the form of bars, cakes or moulded pieces or shapes. In other forms they are to be classified in heading 3405 as “scouring powders and similar preparations”.

3.text: 3. For the purposes of heading 3402, “organic surface-active agents” are products which when mixed with water at a concentration of 0.5 per cent at 200C and left to stand for one hour at the same temperature:

contains.0: (a) give a transparent or translucent liquid or stable emulsion without separation of insoluble matter; and
contains.1: (b) reduce the surface tension of water to 4.5× 10-2N/m (45 dyne/cm) or less.

contains.4: 4. In heading 3403, the expression “petroleum oils and oils obtained from bituminous minerals” applies to the products defined in Note 2 to Chapter 27.

5.text: 5. In heading 3404, subject to the exclusions provided below, the expression ‘artificial waxes and prepared waxes’ applies only to:

contains.1: 2. (A) For the purpose of heading 3822, the expression “certified reference materials” means reference materials which are accompanied by a certificate which indicates the values of the certified properties, the methods used to determine these values and the degree of certainty associated with each value and which are suitable for analytical, calibrating or referencing purposes.
contains.2: (B) With the exception of the products of Chapter 28 or 29, for the class sification of certified reference materials, heading 3822 shall take precedence over any other heading in the Schedule.

3.text: 3. Heading 3824 includes the following goods which are not to be classified in any other heading of this Schedule:

contains.2: (c) Ink removers put up in packings for retail sale;

4.text: 4. Throughout the Schedule, “municipal waste” means waste of a kind collected from households, hotels, restaurants, hospitals, shops, offices, etc., road and pavement sweepings, as well as construction and demolition waste. Municipal waste generally contains a large variety of materials such as plastics, rubber, wood, paper, textiles, glass, metals, food materials, broken furniture and other damaged or discarded articles. The term “municipal waste”, however, does not cover:

contains.0: (a) Individual materials or articles segregated from the waste, such as wastes of plastics, rubber, wood, paper, textiles, glass or metals and spent batteries which fall in their appropriate headings of the Schedule;
contains.2: (c) Waste pharmaceuticals, as defined in Note 4(k) to Chapter 30; or
contains.3: (d) Clinical waste, as defined in Note 6(a) below.

contains.5: 5. For the purposes of heading 3825, “sewage sludge” means sludge arising from urban effluent treatment plant and includes pre-treatment waste, scourings and unstabilised sludge. Stabilised sludge when suitable for use as fertiliser is excluded (Chapter 31).

6.text: 6. For the purposes of heading 3825, the expression “other wastes” applies to:

contains.0: (a) Clinical waste, that is, contaminated waste arising from medical research, diagnosis, treatment or other medical, surgical, dental or veterinary procedures, which often contain pathogens and pharmaceutical substances and require special disposal procedures (for example, soiled dressings, used gloves and used syringes);
contains.2: (c) Wastes of metal pickling liquors, hydraulic fluids, brake fluids and anti-freezing fluids; and
contains.3: (d) Other wastes from chemical or allied industries.

contains.7: The expression “other wastes” does not, however, cover wastes which contain mainly petroleum oils or oils obtained from bituminous minerals (heading 2710).

8.text: 2[7. For the purposes of heading 3826, the term “biodiesel” means mono-alkyl esters of fatty acids of a kind used as a fuel, derived from animal or vegetable fats and oils whether or not used.]

1.text: Plastics and Articles Thereof; Rubber and Articles Thereof

2.text: 1. Goods put up in sets consisting of two or more separate constituents, some or all of which fall in this Section and are intended to be mixed together to obtain a product of Section VI or Section VII, are to be classified in the heading appropriate to that product, provided that the constituents are:

contains.0: (a) having regard to the manner in which they are put up, clearly identifiable as being intended to be used together without first being repacked;
contains.2: (c) identifiable, whether by their nature or by the relative proportions in which they are present, as being complementary one to another.

3480.text: 2. Except for the goods of heading 3918 or 3919, plastics, rubber, and articles thereof, printed with motifs, characters or pictorial representations, which are not merely incidental to the primary use of the goods, fall in Chapter 49.

1.text: Plastics and Articles Thereof

contains.2: 1. Throughout this Schedule, the expression “plastics” means those ma terials of headings 3901 to 3914 which are or have been capable, either at the moment of polymerisation or at some subsequent stage, of being formed under external influence (usually heat and pressure, if necessary with a solvent or plasticiser) by moulding, casting, extruding, rolling or other process into shapes which are retained on the removal of the external influence.
contains.3: Throughout this Schedule, any reference to “plastics” also includes vulcanised fiber. The expression, however, does not apply to materials regarded as textile materials of Section XI.

4.text: 1[2. This Chapter does not cover:

contains.2: (c) separate chemically defined organic compounds (Chapter 29);
contains.3: (d) heparin or its salts (heading 3001);
contains.4: (e) solutions (other than collodions) consisting of any of the products specified in headings 3901 to 3913 in volatile organic solvents when the weight of the solvent exceeds 50% of the weight of the solution (heading 3208); stamping foils of heading 3212;
contains.5: (f) organic surface active agents or preparation of heading 3402;
contains.7: (h) prepared additives for mineral oils (including gasoline) or for other liquids used for the same purposes as mineral oils (heading 3811);
contains.8: (ij) prepared hydraulic fluids based on polyglycols, silicones or other polymers of Chapter 39 (heading 3819);
contains.9: (k) diagnostic or laboratory reagents on a backing of plastics (heading 3822);
contains.10: (l) synthetic rubber, as defined for the purpose of Chapter 40, or articles thereof;
contains.11: (m) saddlery or harness (heading 4201) or trunks, suit--cases, hand--bags or other containers of heading 4202;
contains.12: (n) plaits, wickerwork or other articles of Chapter 46;
contains.14: (p) goods of Section XI (textiles and textile articles);
contains.15: (q) articles of Section XII (for example, footwear, headgear, umbrellas, sun umbrellas, walking-- sticks, whips, riding--crops or parts thereof);
contains.17: (s) articles of Section XVI (machines and mechanical or electrical appliances);
contains.18: (t) parts of aircraft or vehicles of Section XVII;

5.text: 3. Headings 3901 to 3911 apply only to goods of a kind produced by chemical synthesis, falling in the following categories:

contains.0: (a) Liquid synthetic polyolefins of which less than 60% by volume distils at 3000 C, after conversion to 1,013 millibars when a reduced pressure distillation method is used (headings 3901 and 3902);
contains.1: (b) Resins, not highly polymerised, of the coumarone-indene type (heading 3911);
contains.2: (c) Other synthetic polymers with an average of at least 5 monomer units;
contains.3: (d) Silicones (heading 3910);
contains.4: (e) Resols (heading 3909) and other prepolymers.

contains.6: 4. The expression “copolymers” covers all polymers in which no single monomer unit contributes 95% or more by weight to the total polymer content.
contains.7: For the purposes of this Chapter, except where the context otherwise requires, copolymers (including co-polycondensates, co-polyaddition products, block copolymers and graft copolymers) and polymer blends are to be classified in the heading covering polymers of that comonomer unit which predominates by weight over every other single comonomer unit. For the purposes of this Note, constituent comonomer units of polymers falling in the same heading shall be taken together.
contains.8: If no single comonomer unit predominates, copolymers or polymer blends, as the case may be, are to be classified in the heading which occurs last in the numerical order among those which equally merit consideration.
contains.9: 5. Chemically modified polymers, that is those in which only appendages to the main polymer chain have been changed by chemical reaction, are to be classified in the heading appropriate to the unmodified polymer. This provision does not apply to graft copolymers.

10.text: 6. In headings 3901 to 3914, the expression “primary forms” applies only to the following forms:

contains.0: (a) Liquids and pastes, including dispersions (emulsions and suspensions) and solutions;
contains.1: (b) Blocks of irregular shape, lumps, powders (including moulding powders), granules, flakes and similar bulk forms.

contains.11: 7. Heading 3915 does not apply to waste, parings and scrap of a single thermoplastic material, transformed into primary forms (headings 3901 to 3914).
contains.12: 8. For the purposes of heading 3917, the expression “tubes, pipes and hoses” means hollow products, whether semi-manufactures or finished products, of a kind generally used for conveying, conducting or distributing gases or liquids (for example, ribbed garden hose, perforated tubes). This expression also includes sausage casings and other lay-flat tubing. However, except for the last-mentioned, those having an internal cross-section other than round, oval, rectangular (in which the length does not exceed 1.5. times the width) or in the shape of a regular polygon are not to be regarded as tubes, pipes, and hoses but as profile shapes.
contains.13: 9. For the purposes of heading 3918, the expression “wall or ceiling coverings of plastics” applies to products in rolls, of a width not less than 45 cms, suitable for wall or ceiling decoration, consisting of plastics fixed permanently on a backing of any material other than paper, the layer of plastics (on the face side) being grained, embossed, coloured, design-printed or otherwise decorated.
contains.14: 10. In headings 3920 and 3921, the expression “plates, sheets, film, foil and strip” applies only to plates, sheets, film, foil and strip (other than those of Chapter 54) and to blocks of regular geometric shape, whether or not printed or otherwise surface worked, uncut or cut into rectangles (including squares) but not further worked (even if when so cut they become articles ready for use).

15.text: 11. Heading 3925 applies only to the following articles, not being products covered by any of the earlier headings of sub-Chapter II:

contains.0: (a) Reservoirs, tanks (including septic tanks), vats and similar containers, of a capacity exceeding 300L;
contains.1: (b) Structural elements used, for example, in floors, walls or partitions, ceilings or roofs;
contains.2: (c) Gutters and fittings therefor;

3.text: (d) Doors, windows and their frames and thresholds for doors;

contains.4: (e) Balconies, balustrades, fencing, gates and similar barriers;
contains.5: (f) Shutters, blinds (including Venetian blinds) and similar articles and parts and fittings thereof;
contains.6: (g) Large scale shelving for assembly and permanent installation, for example, in shops, workshops, warehouses;
contains.7: (h) Ornamental architectural features, for example, flutings, cupolas, dovecotes; and

8.text: (ij) Fittings and mountings intended for permanent installation in or on doors, windows, staircases, walls or other parts of buildings, for example, knobs, handles, hooks, brackets, towel rails, switch-plates and other protective plates.

16.text: 1. Within any one heading of this Chapter, polymers (including copolymers) and chemically modified polymers are to be classified according to the following provisions:

0.text: (a) Where there is a subheading named “Other” in the same series:

contains.0: (1) The designation in a subheading of a polymer by the prefix “poly” 1[(for example] polyethylene and polyamide-6, 6) means that the constituent monomer unit or monomer units of the named polymer taken together must contribute 95% or more by weight of the total polymer content.
contains.1: (2) The copolymers named in subheading Nos. 3901 30, 2[3901 40,] 3903 20, 3903 30 and 3904 30 are to be classified in those subheadings, provided that the comonomer units of the named copolymers contribute 95% or more by weight of the total polymer content.
contains.2: (3) Chemically modified polymers are to be classified in the subheading named “Other”, provided that the chemically modified polymers are not more specifically covered by another subheading.
contains.3: (4) Polymers not meeting (1), (2) or (3) above, are to be classified in the subheading, among the remaining subheadings in the series, covering polymers of that monomer unit which predominates by weight over every other single comonomer unit. For this purpose, constituent monomer units of polymers falling in the same subheading shall be taken together. Only the constituent comonomer units of the polymers in the series of subheadings under consideration are to be compared.

1.text: (b) Where there is no subheading named “Other” in the same series:

contains.0: (1) Polymers are to be classified in the subheading covering polymers of that monomer unit which predominates by weight over every other single comonomer unit. For this purpose, constituent monomer units of polymers falling in the same subheading shall be taken together. Only the constituent comonomer units of the polymers in the series under consideration are to be compared.
contains.1: (2) Chemically modified polymers are to be classified in the subheading appropriate to the unmodified polymer. Polymer blends are to be classified in the same subheading as polymers of the same monomer units in the same proportions.

contains.17: 2. For the purposes of sub-heading 3920 43, the term “plasticisers” in cludes secondary plasticisers.

1.text: Rubber and Articles Thereof

contains.2: 1. Except where the context otherwise requires, throughout this Schedule the expression “rubber” means the following products, whether or not vulcanised or hard: natural rubber, balata, gutta-percha, guayule, chicle and similar natural gums, synthetic rubber, factice derived from oils, and such substances reclaimed.

3.text: 2. This Chapter does not cover:

contains.0: (a) Goods of Section XI (textiles and textile articles);
contains.1: (b) Footwear or parts thereof of Chapter 64;
contains.2: (c) Headgear or parts thereof (including bathing caps) of Chapter 65;
contains.3: (d) Mechanical or electrical appliances or parts thereof of Section XVI (including electrical goods of all kinds), of hard rubber;
contains.4: (e) Articles of Chapter 90, 92, 94 or 96; or
contains.5: (f) Articles of Chapter 95 (other than sports gloves, mittens and mitts and articles of headings 4011 to 4013).

4.text: 3. In headings 4001 to 4003 and 4005, the expression “primary forms” applies only to the following forms:

contains.0: (a) Liquids and pastes (including latex, whether or not pre-vulcanised, and other dispersions and solutions);
contains.1: (b) Blocks of irregular shape, lumps, bales, powders, granules, crumbs and similar bulk forms.

5.text: 4. In Note 1 to this Chapter and in heading 4002, the expression “synthetic rubber” applies to:

contains.0: (a) Unsaturated synthetic substances which can be irreversibly transformed by vulcanisation with sulphur into non-thermoplastic substances which, at a temperature between 180 C and 290 C, will not break on being extended to three times their original length and will return, after being extended to twice their original length, within a period of five minutes, to a length not greater than one and a half times their original length. For the purposes of this test, substances necessary for the cross-linking, such as vulcanising activators or accelerators, may be added; the presence of substances as provided for by Note 1[5(B)](ii) and (iii) is also permitted. However, the presence of any substances not necessary for the cross-linking, such as extenders, plasticisers and fillers, is not permitted;
contains.2: (c) Natural rubber modified by grafting or mixing with plastics, depolymerised natural rubber, mixtures of unsaturated synthetic substances with saturated synthetic high polymers provided that all the above-mentioned products comply with the requirements concerning vulcanisation, elongation and recovery in (a) above.

6.text: 5. 1[(A)] Headings 4001 and 4002 do not apply to any rubber or mixture of rubbers which has been compounded, before or after coagulation, with:

contains.0: (i) vulcanising agents, accelerators, retarders or activators (other than those added for the preparation of pre-vulcanised rubber latex);
contains.1: (ii) pigments or other colouring matter, other than those added solely for the purpose of identification;
contains.2: (iii) plasticisers or extenders (except mineral oil in the case of oil-extended rubber), fillers, reinforcing agents, organic solvents or any other substances, except those permitted under (b);

7.text: 1[(B)] The presence of the following substances in any rubber or mixture of rubbers shall not affect its classification in heading 4001 or 4002, as the case may be, provided that such rubber or mixture of rubbers retains its essential character as a raw material:

contains.1: (ii) small amounts of breakdown products of emulsifiers;
contains.2: (iii) very small amounts of the following: heat-sensitive agents (generally for obtaining thermosensitive rubber latexes), cationic surface-active agents (generally for obtaining electro-positive rubber latexes), anti-oxidants, coagulants, crumbling agents, freeze-resisting agents, peptisers, preservatives, 2[stabilisers], viscosity-control agents, or similar special-purpose additives.

contains.8: 6. For the purposes of heading 4004, the expression “waste, parings and scrap” means rubber waste, parings and scrap from the manufacture or working of rubber and rubber goods definitely not usable as such because of cutting-up, wear or other reasons.
contains.9: 7. Thread wholly of vulcanised rubber, of which any cross-sectional dimension exceeds 5 mm, is to be classified as strip, rods or profile shapes, of heading 4008.
contains.10: 8. Heading 4010 includes conveyor or transmission belts or belting of textile fabric impregnated, coated, covered or laminated with rubber or made from textile yarn or cord impregnated, coated, covered or sheathed with rubber.
contains.11: 9. In headings 4001, 4002, 4003, 4005 and 4008, the expressions “plates”, “sheets” and “strip” apply only to plates, sheets and strip and to blocks of regular geometric shape, uncut or simply cut to rectangular (including square) shape, whether or not having the character of articles and whether or not printed or otherwise surface-worked, but not otherwise cut to shape or further worked.

12.text: In heading 4008 the expressions “rods” and “profile shapes” apply only to such products, whether or not cut to length or surface-worked but not otherwise worked.

contains.13: 1. For the purposes of headings 4009 and 4010, while calculating the percentage of rubber compound contents, the weight of canvas, yarn, metallic wires, washers, rivets and the like, where such products, form integral part of ingredient of such rubber products, shall be taken into account, but the weight of metallic fitments and surface finishing necessary to make the belting and tubing suitable for particular end uses, shall be ignored.
contains.14: 2. Tariff item 4008 21 10 shall also apply to “plates”, “sheets”, and “strips”, whether or not cut to shape and surface-worked or further worked so as to render them fit for resoling or repairing or re- treading of rubber tyres.

3.text: 2. This Chapter does not cover:

In this Chapter, the expression “densified wood” means wood which has been subjected to chemical or physical treatment (being, in the case of layers bonded together, treatment in excess of that needed to ensure a good bond), and which has thereby acquired increased density or hardness together with improved mechanical strength or resistance to chemical or electrical agencies.

Such pellets are cylindrical, with a diameter not exceeding 25 mm and a length not exceeding 100 mm.

Except where heading 4803 otherwise requires, these headings do not apply to paper, paperboard, cellulose wadding or webs of cellulose fibers which have been otherwise processed.

13.text: 9. For the purposes of heading 4814, the expression “wallpaper and similar wall coverings” applies only to:

0.text: (a) Paper in rolls, of a width of not less than 45 cm and not more than 160 cm, suitable for wall or ceiling decoration:

contains.0: (i) Grained, embossed, surface-coloured, design-printed or otherwise surface-decorated (2[for example], with textile flock), whether or not coated or covered with transparent protective plastics;

34.text: Printed books, newspapers, pictures and other products of the printing industry; manuscripts, typescripts and plans

1.text: 1. This Chapter does not cover:

contains.0: (a) Photographic negatives or positives on transparent bases (Chapter 37);
contains.1: (b) Maps, plans or globes, in relief, whether or not printed (heading 9023);
contains.2: (c) Playing cards or other goods of Chapter 95; or
contains.3: (d) Original engravings, prints or lithographs (heading 9702), postage or revenue stamps, stamp-postmarks, first-day covers, postal stationery or the like of heading 9704, antiques of an age exceeding one hundred years or other articles of Chapter 97.

contains.2: 2. For the purposes of Chapter 49, the term “printed” also means reproduced by means of a duplicating machine, produced under the control of an automatic data processing machine, embossed, photographed, photocopied, thermo copied or typewritten.
contains.3: 3. Newspapers, journals and periodicals which are bound otherwise than in paper, and sets of newspapers, journals or periodicals comprising more than one number under a single cover are to be classified in heading 4901, whether or not containing advertising material.

4.text: 4. Heading 4901 also covers:

contains.0: (a) A collection of printed reproductions of, for example, works of art or drawings, with a relative text, put up with numbered pages in a form suitable for binding into one or more volumes;
contains.1: (b) A pictorial supplement accompanying, and subsidiary to, a bound volume; and
contains.2: (c) Printed parts of books or booklets, in the form of assembled or separate sheets or signatures, constituting the whole or a part of a complete work and designed for binding.

27.text: However, printed pictures or illustrations not bearing a text, whether in the form of signatures or separate sheets, fall in heading 4911.

contains.0: 5. Subject to Note 3 to this Chapter, heading 4901 does not cover publications which are essentially devoted to advertising (for example, brochures, pamphlets, leaflets, trade catalogues, year books published by trade associations, tourist propaganda). Such publications are to be classified in heading 4911.

1.text: 6. For the purposes of heading 4903, the expression “children's picture books” means books for children in which the pictures form the principal interest and the text is subsidiary.

contains.28: For the purposes of tariff item 4907 00 30, “Information Technology software” means any representation of instructions, data, sound or image, including source code and object code, recorded in a machine readable form, and capable of being manipulated or providing interactivity to a user, by means of an automatic data processing machine.

contains.21: 2[(A) Goods classifiable in Chapters 50 to 55 or in heading 5809 or 5902 and of a mixture of two or more textile materials are to be classified as if consisting wholly of that one textile material which predominates by weight over any other single textile material.
contains.22: When no one textile material predominates by weight, the goods are to be classified as if consisting wholly of that one textile material which is covered by the heading which occurs last in numerical order among those which equally merit consideration.]

23.text: (B) For the purposes of the above rule:-

contains.0: (a) Gimped horsehair yarn (heading 5110) and metallised yarn (heading 5605) are to be treated as a single textile material the weight of which is to be taken as the aggregate of the weights of its components; for the classification of woven fabrics, metal thread is to be regarded as a textile material;
contains.1: (b) The choice of appropriate heading shall be effected by determining first the Chapter and then the applicable heading within that Chapter, disregarding any materials not classified in that Chapter;
contains.2: (c) When both Chapters 54 and 55 are involved with any other Chapter, Chapters 54 and 55 are to be treated as a single Chapter;
contains.3: (d) Where a Chapter or a heading refers to goods of different textile materials, such materials are to be treated as a single textile material.

contains.24: (C) The provisions of paragraphs (A) and (B) above apply also to the yarns referred to in Note 3, 4, 5 or 6 below.

3.text: 3. (A) For the purposes of this Section, and subject to the exceptions in paragraph (B) below, yarns [single, multiple (folded) or cabled] of the following descriptions are to be treated as “twine, cordage, ropes and cables”:

contains.0: (a) Of silk or waste silk, measuring more than 20,000 decitex;
contains.1: (b) Of man-made fibers (including yarn of two or more monofilaments of Chapter 54), measuring more than 10,000 decitex;

contains.0: (i) Polished or glazed, measuring 1,429 decitex or more; or
contains.1: (ii) Not polished or glazed, measuring more than 20,000 decitex;

contains.3: (d) Of coir, consisting of three or more plies;
contains.4: (e) Of other vegetable fibers, measuring more than 20,000 decitex; or
contains.5: (f) Reinforced with metal thread.

4.text: (B) Exceptions:

contains.0: (a) Yarn of wool or other animal hair and paper yarn, other than yarn reinforced with metal thread;
contains.1: (b) Man-made filament tow of Chapter 55 and multifilament yarn without twist or with a twist of less than 5 turns per meter of Chapter 54;
contains.2: (c) Silk worm gut of heading 5006 and monofilaments of Chapter 54;
contains.3: (d) Metallised yarn of heading 5605; yarn reinforced with metal thread is subject to paragraph (A) (f) above; and
contains.4: (e) Chenille yarn, gimped yarn and loop wale-yarn of heading 5606.

5.text: 4. (A) For the purposes of Chapters 50, 51, 52, 54 and 55, the expression “put up for retail sale” in relation to yarn means, subject to the exceptions in paragraph (B) below, yarn [single, multiple (folded) or cabled)] put up:

0.text: (a) On cards, reels, tubes or similar supports, of a weight (including support) not exceeding:

contains.0: (i) 85 g in the case of silk, waste silk or man-made filament yarn; or

1.text: (b) In balls, hanks or skeins of a weight not exceeding:

contains.0: (i) 85 g in the case of man-made filament yarn of less than 3,000 decitex, silk or silk waste;
contains.1: (ii) 125 g in the case of all other yarns of less than 2,000 decitex; or
contains.2: (iii) 500 g in other cases;

2.text: (c) In hanks or skeins comprising several smaller hanks or skeins separated by dividing threads which render them independent one of the other, each of uniform weight not exceeding:

contains.0: (i) 85 g in the case of silk, waste silk or man-made filament yarn; or

3.text: (B) Exceptions:

0.text: (a) Single yarn of any textile material, except:

contains.0: (i) Single yarn of wool or fine animal hair, unbleached; and
contains.1: (ii) Single yarn of wool or fine animal hair, bleached, dyed or printed, measuring more than 5,000 decitex;

4.text: (b) Multiple (folded) or cabled yarn, unbleached:

0.text: (i) Of silk or waste silk, however put up; or

contains.1: (ii) Of other textile material except wool or fine animal hair, in hanks or skeins;
contains.2: (c) Multiple (folded) or cabled yarn of silk or waste silk, bleached, dyed or printed, measuring 133 decitex or less; and

3.text: (d) Single, multiple (folded) or cabled yarn of any textile material:

contains.0: (i) In cross-reeled hanks or skeins; or
contains.1: (ii) Put up on supports or in some other manner indicating its use in the textile industry (for example, on cops, twisting mill tubes, pirns, conical bobbins or spindles, or reeled in the form of cocoons for embroidery looms).

5.text: 5. For the purposes of headings 5204, 5401 and 5508 the expression “sewing thread” means multiple (folded) or cabled yarn:

contains.0: (a) Put up on supports (for example, reels, tubes) of a weight (including support) not exceeding 1,000 g;
contains.1: (b) Dressed for use as sewing thread; and
contains.2: (c) With a final “Z” twist.

contains.6: 6. For the purposes of this Section, the expression “high tenacity yarn” means yarn having a tenacity, expressed in cN/tex (centinewtons per tex), greater than the following:
contains.7: Single yarn of nylon or other polyamides, or of polyesters 60cN/tex
contains.8: Multiple (folded) or cabled yarn of nylon or other polyamides, or of polyesters 53cN/tex
contains.9: Single, multiple (folded) or cabled yarn of viscose rayon 27cN/tex

10.text: 7. For the purposes of this Section, the expression “made up” means:

contains.0: (a) Cut otherwise than into squares or rectangles;
contains.1: (b) Produced in the finished state, ready for use (or merely needing separation by cutting dividing threads) without sewing or other working (for example, certain dusters, towels, table cloths, scarf squares, blankets);
contains.2: 1[(c) Cut to size and with at least one heat-sealed edge with a visibly tapered or compressed border and the other edges treated as described in any other sub-clause of this Note, but excluding fabrics the cut edges of which have been prevented from unravelling by hot cutting or by other simple means;];
contains.3: 2[(d)] Hemmed or with rolled edges, or with a knotted fringe at any of the edges, but excluding fabrics the cut edges of which have been prevented from unravelling by whipping or by other simple means;
contains.4: 3[(e)] Cut to size and having undergone a process of drawn thread work;
contains.5: 1[(f)] Assembled by sewing, gumming or otherwise (other than piece goods consisting of two or more lengths of identical material joined end to end and piece goods composed of two or more textiles assembled in layers, whether or not padded);
contains.6: 2[(g)] Knitted or crocheted to shape, whether presented as separate items or in the form of a number of items in the length.]

11.text: 8. For the purposes of Chapters 50 to 60:

contains.0: (a) Chapters 50 to 55 and 60 and, except where the context otherwise requires, Chapters 56 to 59 do not apply to goods made up within the meaning of Note 7 above; and
contains.1: (b) Chapters 50 to 55 and 60 do not apply to goods of Chapters 56 to 59.

contains.12: 9. The woven fabrics of Chapters 50 to 55 include fabrics consisting of layers of parallel textile yarns superimposed on each other at acute or right angles. These layers are bonded at the intersections of the yarns by an adhesive or by thermal bonding.
contains.13: 10. Elastic products consisting of textile materials combined with rubber threads are classified in this Section.
contains.14: 11. For the purposes of this Section, the expression “impregnated” in cludes “dipped”.
contains.15: 12. For the purposes of this Section, the expression “polyamides” in cludes “aramids”.
contains.16: 3[13. For the purposes of this Section and, where applicable, throughout this Schedule, the expression “electromeric yarn” means filament yarn, including monofilament, of synthetic textile material, other than textured yarn, which does not break on being extended to three times its original length and which returns, after being extended to twice its original length, within a period of five minutes, to a length not greater than one and a half times its original length.

17.text: 14. Unless the context otherwise requires, textile garments of different headings are to be classified in their own headings even if put up in sets for retail sale. For the purposes of this Note, the expression “textile garments” means garments of headings 6101 to 6114 and headings 6201 to 6211.]

contains.18: 1. In this Section and, where applicable, throughout this Schedule, the following expressions have the meanings hereby assigned to them:

contains.0: (i) has the natural colour of its constituent fibers and has not been bleached, dyed (whether or not in the mass) or printed; or
contains.1: (ii) is of indeterminate colour (“grey yarn”), manufactured from garnetted stock.

60.text: Such yarn may have been treated with a colourless dressing or fugitive dye (which disappears after simple washing with soap) and, in the case of man-made fibers, treated in the mass with delustring agents (for example, titanium dioxide).

contains.0: (i) has undergone a bleaching process, is made of bleached fibers or, unless the context otherwise requires, has been dyed white (whether or not in the mass) or treated with a white dressing;
contains.1: (ii) consists of a mixture of unbleached and bleached fibers; or
contains.2: (iii) is multiple (folded) or cabled and consists of unbleached and bleached yarns.

1.text: 2[(c)] Coloured (dyed or printed) yarn: Yarn which:

contains.0: (i) is dyed (whether or not in the mass) other than white or in a fugitive colour, or printed, or made from dyed or printed fibers;
contains.1: (ii) consists of a mixture of dyed fibers of different colours or of a mixture of unbleached or bleached fibers with coloured fibers (marl or mixture yarns), or is printed in one or more colours at intervals to give the impression of dots;
contains.2: (iii) is obtained from slivers or rovings which have been printed; or
contains.3: (iv) is multiple (folded) or cabled and consists of unbleached or bleached yarn and coloured yarn.

61.text: The above definitions also apply, mutatis mutandis, to monofilament and to strip or the like of Chapter 54.

contains.0: 3[(d)] Unbleached woven fabric: Woven fabric made from unbleached yarn and which has not been bleached, dyed or printed. Such fabric may have been treated with a colourless dressing or a fugitive dye.

1.text: 4[(e)] Bleached woven fabric: Woven fabric which:

contains.0: (i) has been bleached or, unless the context otherwise requires, dyed white or treated with a white dressing, in the piece;
contains.2: (iii) consists of unbleached and bleached yarn.

2.text: 5[(f)] Dyed woven fabric: Woven fabric which:

contains.0: (i) is dyed a single uniform colour other than white (unless the context otherwise requires) or has been treated with a coloured finish other than white (unless the context otherwise requires), in the piece; or
contains.1: (ii) consists of coloured yarn of a single uniform colour.

3.text: 1[(g)] Woven fabric of yarns of different colours: Woven fabric (other than printed woven fabric) which:

contains.0: (i) consists of yarns of different colours or yarns of different shades of the same colour (other than the natural colour of the constituent fibers);
contains.1: (ii) consists of unbleached or bleached yarn and coloured yarn; or
contains.2: (iii) consists of marl or mixture yarns.

4.text: (In all cases, the yarn used in selvedges and piece ends is not taken into consideration).

contains.0: 2[(h)] Printed woven fabric: Woven fabric which has been printed in the piece, whether or not made from yarns of different colours.
contains.1: (The following are also regarded as printed woven fabrics: woven fabrics bearing designs made, for example, with a brush or spray gun, by means of transfer paper, by flocking or by the batik process.)
contains.2: The process of mercerisation does not affect the classification of yarns or fabrics within the above categories.
contains.3: The 3[definitions at (d) to (h)] above apply, mutatis mutandis, to knitted or crocheted fabrics.
contains.4: 4[(ij)] Plain weave: A fabric construction in which each yarn of the weft passes alternately over and under the successive yarns of the warp and each yarn of the warp passes alternatively over and under successive yarns of the weft.

contains.5: 2. (A) Products of Chapters 56 to 63 containing two or more textile materials are to be regarded as consisting wholly of that textile material which would be selected under Note 2 to this Section for the classification of a product of Chapters 50 to 55 or of heading 5809 consisting of the same textile materials.

6.text: (B) For the application of this rule:

contains.0: (a) where appropriate, only the part which determines the classification under Interpretative Rule 3 shall be taken into account;
contains.1: (b) in the case of textile products consisting of a ground fabric and a pile or looped surface no account shall be taken of the ground fabric;

2.text: (c) in the case of embroidery of heading 5810 and goods thereof, only the ground fabric shall be taken into account. However, embroidery without visible ground, and goods thereof, shall be classified with reference to the embroidering threads alone.

1.text: 1[Man-made filaments; strip and the like of man-made textile materials]

97.text: 2[1. Throughout this Schedule, the term’ man made fibers’ means staple fibers and filaments of organic polymers produced by manufacturing processes either:

contains.0: (a) by polymerisation of organic monomers to produce polymers such as polyamides, polyesters, polyolefins or polyurethanes, or by chemical modification of polymers produced by this process (for

98.text: example, poly(vinyl alcohol) prepared by the hydrolysis of poly(vinyl acetate)); or

contains.0: (b) by dissolution or chemical treatment of natural organic polymers (for example, cellulose) to

contains.99: produce polymers such as cuprammonium rayon (cupro) or viscose rayon, or by chemical modification of natural organic polymers (for example, cellulose, casein and other proteins, or alginic

100.text: acid), to produce polymers such as cellulose acetate or alginates.

contains.0: The terms “synthetic” and “artificial”, used in relation to fibers, mean: synthetic: fibers as defined

101.text: at (a); artificial: fibers as defined at (b). Strip and the like of heading 5404 or 5405 are not considered to be man--made fibers.

contains.0: The terms “man--made”, “synthetic” and “artificial” shall have the same meaning when used in relation to “textile materials”.]

contains.3: (d) Synthetic filament tow only; the tow must be drawn, that is to say, be incapable of being stretched by more than 100% of its length;

contains.15: Tow of a length not exceeding 2 m is to be classified in heading 5503 or 5504.

624.text: Wadding, Felt and Nonwovens; Special Yarns; Twine, Cordage, Ropes and Cables and Articles Thereof

contains.0: (a) Wadding, felt or nonwovens, impregnated, coated or covered with substances or preparations (for example, perfumes or cosmetics of Chapter 33, soaps or detergents of heading 3401, polishes, creams or similar preparations of heading 3405, fabric softeners of heading 3809) where the textile material is present merely as a carrying medium;
contains.2: (c) Natural or artificial abrasive powder or grain, on a backing of felt or nonwovens (heading 6805);
contains.3: (d) Agglomerated or reconstituted mica, on a backing of felt or nonwovens (heading 6814); [***]1
contains.4: (e) Metal foil on a backing of felt or nonwovens 2[(generally Section XIV or XV)].
contains.5: 3[(f) Sanitary towels (pads) and tampons, napkins and napkin liners for babies and similar articles of heading 9619.]
contains.6: 2. The term “felt” includes needleloom felt and fabrics consisting of a web of textile fibers the cohesion of which has been enhanced by a stitch-bonding process using fibers from the web itself.
contains.7: 3. Headings 5602 and 5603 cover respectively felt and nonwovens impregnated, coated, covered or laminated with plastics or rubber whatever the nature of these materials (compact or cellular).
contains.8: Heading 5603 also includes nonwovens in which plastics or rubber forms the bonding substance.

9.text: Headings 5602 and 5603 do not, however, cover:

contains.0: (a) Felt impregnated, coated, covered or laminated with plastics or rubber, containing 50 per cent or less by weight of textile material or felt completely embedded in plastics or rubber (Chapter 39 or 40);
contains.1: (b) Nonwovens, either completely embedded in plastics or rubber, or entirely coated or covered on both sides with such materials, provided that such coating or covering can be seen with the naked eye with no account being taken of any resulting change of colour (Chapter 39 or 40); or
contains.2: (c) Plates, sheets or strip of cellular plastics or cellular rubber combined with felt or nonwovens, where the textile material is present merely for reinforcing purposes (Chapter 39 or 40).
contains.3: 4. Heading 5604 does not cover textile yarn, or strip or the like of heading 5404 or 5405, in which the impregnation, coating or covering cannot be seen with the naked eye (usually Chapters 50 to 55); for the purpose of this provision, no account should be taken of any resulting change of colour.

contains.817: 1. This Chapter does not apply to textile fabrics referred to in Note 1 to Chapter 59, impregnated,
contains.818: coated, covered or laminated, or to other goods of Chapter 59.
contains.819: 2. Heading 5801 also includes woven weft pile fabrics which have not yet had the floats cut, at which
contains.820: stage they have no pile standing up.
contains.821: 3. For the purposes of heading 5803, “gauze” means a fabric with a warp composed wholly or in part of standing or ground threads and crossing or doup threads which cross the standing or ground threads
contains.822: making a half turn, a complete turn or more to form loops through which weft threads pass.
contains.823: 4. Heading 5804 does not apply to knotted net fabrics of twine, cordage or rope, of heading 5608.

824.text: 5. For the purposes of heading 5806, the expression “narrow woven fabrics” means:

contains.0: (a) Woven fabrics of a width not exceeding 30 cm, whether woven as such or cut from wider pieces, provided with selvedges (woven, gummed or otherwise made) on both edges;
contains.1: (b) Tubular woven fabrics of a flattened width not exceeding 30 cm; and
contains.2: (c) Bias binding with folded edges, of a width when unfolded not exceeding 30 cm.

contains.825: Narrow woven fabrics with woven fringes are to be classified in heading 5808.
contains.826: 6. In heading 5810, the expression “embroidery” means, inter alia, embroidery with metal or glass

1.text: Articles of Apparel and Clothing Accessories, Knitted or Crocheted

contains.2: 1. This Chapter applies only to made up knitted or crocheted articles.

3.text: 2. This Chapter does not cover:

contains.1: (b) Worn clothing or other worn articles of heading 6309; or
contains.2: (c) Orthopedic appliances, surgical belts, trusses or the like (heading 9021).

4.text: 3. For the purposes of headings 6103 and 6104:

0.text: (a) The term “suit” means a set of garments composed of two or three pieces made up, in respect of their outer surface, in identical fabric and comprising:

contains.0: (i) one suit coat or jacket the outer shell of which, exclusive of sleeves, consists of four or more panels, designed to cover the upper part of the body, possibly with a tailored waistcoat in addition whose front is made from the same fabric as the outer surface of the other components of the set and whose back is made from the same fabric as the lining of the suit coat or jacket; and
contains.1: (ii) one garment designed to cover the lower part of the body and consisting of trousers, breeches or shorts (other than swimwear), a skirt or a divided skirt, having neither braces nor bibs.

contains.5: All of the components of a “suit” must be of the same fabric construction, colour and composition; they must also be of the same style and of corresponding or compatible size. However, these components may have a piping (a strip of fabric sewn into the seam) in a different fabric.
contains.6: If several separate components to cover the lower part of the body are presented together (for example, two pairs of trousers or trousers and shorts, or a skirt or divided skirt and trousers), the constituent lower part shall be one pair of trousers or, in the case of women's or girls' suits, the skirt or divided skirt, the other garments being considered separately.

7.text: The term “suit” includes the following sets of garments, whether or not they fulfill all the above conditions:

contains.0: (a) morning dress, comprising a plain jacket (cutaway) with rounded tails hanging well down at the back and striped trousers;
contains.1: (b) evening dress (tailcoat), generally made of black fabric, the jacket of which is relatively short at the front, does not close and has narrow skirts cut in at the hips and hanging down behind;
contains.2: (c) dinner jacket suits, in which the jacket is similar in style to an ordinary jacket (though perhaps revealing more of the shirt front), but has shiny silk or imitation silk lapels.

3.text: (d) The term “ensemble” means a set of garments (other than suits and articles of heading 6107, 6108 or 6109), composed of several pieces made up in identical fabric, put up for retail sale, and comprising:

contains.0: 1 (i) one garment designed to cover the upper part of the body, with the exception of pullovers which may form a second upper garment in the sole context of twin sets, and of waistcoats which may also form a second upper garment, and
contains.1: (ii) one or two different garments, designed to cover the lower part of the body and consisting of trousers, bib and brace overalls, breeches, shorts (other than swim-wear), a skirt or a divided skirt.

contains.8: All of the components of an ensemble must be of the same fabric construction, style, colour and composition; they also must be of corresponding or compatible size. The term “ensemble” does not apply to track suits or ski suits, of heading 6112.
contains.9: 4. Headings 6105 and 6106 do not cover garments with pockets below the waist, with a ribbed waistband or other means of tightening at the bottom of the garment or garments having an average of less than 10 stitches per linear centimeter in each direction counted on an area measuring at least 10 cm x 10 cm. Heading 6105 does not cover sleeveless garments.
contains.10: 5. Heading 6109 does not cover garments with a drawstring, ribbed waistband or other means of tightening at the bottom of the garment.

contains.0: (a) The expression “babies' garments and clothing accessories” means articles for young children of a body height not exceeding 86 cm; [***]1
contains.1: (b) Articles which are, prima facie, classifiable both in heading 6111 and in other headings of this Chapter are to be classified in heading 6111.

12.text: 7. For the purposes of heading 6112, “ski suits” means garments or sets of garments which, by their general appearance and texture, are identifiable as intended to be worn principally for skiing (cross- country or alpine). They consist either of:

contains.0: (a) A “ski overall”, that is, a one-piece garment designed to cover the upper and the lower parts of the body; in addition to sleeves and a collar, the ski overall may have pockets or foot straps; or

1.text: (b) a “ski ensemble”, that is, a set of garments composed of two or three pieces put up for retail sale and comprising:

contains.0: (i) one garment such as an anorak, wind-cheater, wind-jacket or similar article, closed by a slide fastener (zipper), possibly with a waistcoat in addition, and
contains.1: (ii) one pair of trousers whether or not extending above waist-level, one pair of breeches or one bib and brace overall.

contains.13: The “ski ensemble” may also consist of an overall similar to the one mentioned in paragraph (a) above and a type of padded sleeveless jacket worn over the overall.
contains.14: All the components of a “ski ensemble” must be made up in a fabric of the same texture, style and composition whether or not of the same colour; they also must be of corresponding or compatible size.
contains.15: 8. Garments which are, prima facie, classifiable both in heading 6113 and in other headings of this Chapter, excluding heading 6111, are to be classified in heading 6113.
contains.16: 9. Garments of this Chapter designed for left over right closure at the front shall be regarded as men's or boys' garments, and those designed for right over left closure at the front as women's or girls' garments. These provisions do not apply where the cut of the garment clearly indicates that it is designed for one or other of the sexes.
contains.17: Garments which cannot be identified as either men's or boys' garments or as women's or girls' garments are to be classified in the headings covering women's or girls' garments.
contains.18: 10. Articles of this Chapter may be made of metal thread.

0.text: Articles of Apparel and Clothing Accessories, Not Knitted or Crocheted

contains.1: 1. This Chapter applies only to made up articles of any textile fabric other than wadding, excluding knitted or crocheted articles (other than those of heading 6212).

contains.0: (a) Worn clothing or other worn articles of heading 6309; or
contains.1: (b) Orthopaedic appliances, surgical belts, trusses or the like (heading 9021).

3.text: 3. For the purposes of headings 6203 and 6204:

0.text: (a) The term “suit” means a set of garments composed of two or three pieces made up, in respect of their outer surface, in identical fabric and comprising:

contains.0: - one suit coat or jacket the outer shell of which, exclusive of sleeves, consists of four or more panels, designed to cover the upper part of the body, possibly with a tailored waistcoat in addition whose front is made from the same fabric as the outer surface of the other components of the set and whose back is made from the same fabric as the lining of the suit coat or jacket; and
contains.1: - one garment designed to cover the lower part of the body and consisting of trousers, breeches or shorts (other than swimwear), a skirt or a divided skirt, having neither braces nor bibs.
contains.2: All of the components of a “suit” must be of the same fabric construction, colour and composition; they must also be of the same style and of corresponding or compatible size. However, these components may have a piping (a strip of fabric sewn into the seam) in a different fabric.
contains.3: If several separate components to cover the lower part of the body are presented together (for example, two pairs of trousers or trousers and shorts, or a skirt or divided skirt and trousers), the constituent lower part shall be one pair of trousers or, in the case of women's or girls' suits, the skirt or divided skirt, the other garments being considered separately.
contains.4: The term “suit” includes the following sets of garments, whether or not they fulfilll all the above conditions:
contains.5: (a) morning dress, comprising a plain jacket (cutaway) with rounded tails hanging well down at the back and striped trousers;
contains.6: (b) evening dress (tailcoat), generally made of black fabric, the jacket of which is relatively short at the front, does not close and has narrow skirts cut in at the hips and hanging down behind;
contains.7: (c) dinner jacket suits, in which the jacket is similar in style to an ordinary jacket (though perhaps revealing more of the shirt front), but has shiny silk or imitation silk lapels.

1.text: (b) The term “ensemble” means a set of garments (other than suits and articles of heading 6207 or 6208), composed of several pieces made up in identical fabric, put up for retail sale, and comprising:

contains.0: - one garment designed to cover the upper part of the body, with the exception of waistcoats which may also form a second upper garment, and

1.text: - one or two different garments, designed to cover the lower part of the body and consisting of trousers, bib and brace overalls, breeches, shorts (other than swimwear), a skirt or a divided skirt.

contains.2: All of the components of an ensemble must be of the same fabric construction, style, colour and composition; they also must be of 1[corresponding or compatible size]. The term “ensemble” does not apply to track suits or ski suits, of heading 6211.

4.text: 4. For the purposes of heading 6209:

contains.0: (a) The expression “babies' garments and clothing accessories” means articles for young children of a body height not exceeding 86 cm; 2[***];
contains.1: (b) Articles which are, prima facie, classifiable both in heading 6209 and in other headings of this Chapter are to be classified in heading 6209.

contains.5: 5. Garments which are, prima facie, classifiable both in heading 6210 and in other headings of this Chapter, excluding heading 6209, are to be classified in heading 6210.

6.text: 6. For the purposes of heading 6211, “ski suits” means garments or sets of garments which, by their general appearance and texture, are identifiable as intended to be worn principally for skiing (cross- country or alpine). They consist either of:

contains.0: (a) A “ski overall”, that is, a one-piece garment designed to cover the upper and the lower parts of the body; in addition to sleeves and a collar the ski overall may have pockets or foot straps; or

1.text: (b) a “ski ensemble”, that is, a set of garments composed of two or three pieces, put up for retail sale and comprising:

contains.0: - one garment such as an anorak, wind-cheater, wind-jacket or similar article, closed by a slide fastener (zipper), possibly with a waistcoat in addition, and
contains.1: - one pair of trousers whether or not extending above waist-level, one pair of breeches or one bib and brace overall.
contains.2: The “ski ensemble” may also consist of an overall similar to the one mentioned in paragraph (a) above and a type of padded, sleeveless jacket worn over the overall.
contains.3: All the components of a “ski ensemble” must be made up in a fabric of the same texture, style and composition whether or not of the same colour; they also must be of corresponding or compatible size.

contains.7: 7. Scarves and articles of the scarf type, square or approximately square, of which no side exceeds 60 cm., are to be classified as handkerchiefs (heading 6213). Handkerchiefs of which any side exceeds 60 cm. are to be classified in heading 6214.
contains.8: 8. Garments of this Chapter designed for left over right closure at the front shall be regarded as men's or boys' garments, and those designed for right over left closure at the front as women's or girls' garments. These provisions do not apply where the cut of the garment clearly indicates that it is designed for one or other of the sexes.
contains.9: Garments which cannot be identified as either men's or boys' garments or as women's or girls' garments are to be classified in the headings covering women's or girls' garments.

10.text: 9. Articles of this Chapter may be made of metal thread.

11.text: For the purpose of this Chapter, “Khadi” means,--

contains.0: (a) the article of apparel or clothing accessories, made from any cloth woven on handlooms in India from cotton, silk or woollen yarn handspun in India or from a mixture of any two or all of such yarns; and
contains.1: (b) produced by a person certified or recognised by the Khadi Village Industries Commission established under section 4 of the Khadi and Village Industries Commission Act, 1956 (61 of 1956).]

2.text: Base Metals and Articles of Base Metal

3.text: 1. This Section does not cover:

contains.0: (a) Prepared paints, inks or other products with a basis of metallic flakes or powder (headings 3207 to 3210, 3212, 3213 or 3215);
contains.2: (c) Headgear or parts thereof of heading 6506 or 6507;
contains.3: (d) Umbrella frames or other articles of heading 6603;
contains.4: (e) Goods of Chapter 71 (for example, precious metal alloys, base metal clad with precious metal, imitation jewellery);
contains.5: (f) Articles of Section XVI (machinery, mechanical appliances and electrical goods);
contains.6: (g) Assembled railway or tramway track (heading 8608) or other articles of Section XVII (vehicles, ships and boats, aircraft);
contains.7: (h) Instruments or apparatus of Section XVIII, including clock or watch springs;
contains.8: (ij) Lead shot prepared for ammunition (heading 9306) or other articles of Section XIX (arms and ammunition);
contains.9: (k) Articles of Chapter 94 (for example, furniture, mattress supports, lamps and lighting fittings, illuminated signs, prefabricated buildings);
contains.10: (l) Articles of Chapter 95 (for example, toys, games, sports requisites);
contains.11: (m) Hand sieves, buttons, pens, pencil-holders, pen nibs or other articles of Chapter 96 (miscellaneous manufactured articles); or
contains.12: (n) Articles of Chapter 97 (for example, works of art).

4.text: 2. Throughout this Schedule the expression “parts of general use” means:

contains.0: (a) Articles of heading 7307, 7312, 7315, 7317 or 7318 and similar articles of other base metal;
contains.1: (b) Springs and leaves for springs, of base metal, other than clock or watch springs (heading 9114); and
contains.2: (c) Articles of headings 8301, 8302, 8308, 8310 and frames and mirrors, of base metal, of heading 8306.

contains.5: In Chapters 73 to 76 and 78 to 82 (but not in heading 7315) references to parts of goods do not include references to parts of general use as defined above.

6.text: Subject to the preceding paragraph and to Note 1 to Chapter 83, the articles of Chapter 82 or 83 are excluded from Chapters 72 to 76 and 78 to 81.

contains.7: 3. Throughout this Schedule, the expression “base metals” means: iron and steel, copper, nickel, aluminum, lead, zinc, tin, tungsten (wolfram), molybdenum, tantalum, magnesium, cobalt, bismuth, cadmium, titanium, zirconium, antimony, manganese, beryllium, chromium, germanium, vanadium, gallium, hafnium, indium, niobium (columbium), rhenium and thallium.
contains.8: 4. Throughout this Schedule, the term “cermets” means products containing a microscopic heterogeneous combination of a metallic component and a ceramic component. The term “cermets” includes sintered metal carbides (metal carbides sintered with a metal).

9.text: 5. Classification of alloys (other than ferro-alloys and master alloys as defined in Chapters 72 and 74):

contains.0: (a) An alloy of base metals is to be classified as an alloy of the metal which predominates by weight over each of the other metals;
contains.1: (b) An alloy composed of base metals of this Section and of elements not falling within this Section is to be treated as an alloy of base metals of this Section if the total weight of such metals equals or exceeds the total weight of the other elements present;
contains.2: (c) In this Section the term “alloys” includes sintered mixtures of metal powders, heterogeneous intimate mixtures obtained by melting (other than cermets) and intermetallic compounds.

contains.10: 6. Unless the context otherwise requires, any reference in this Schedule to a base metal includes a reference to alloys which, by virtue of Note 5 above, are to be classified as alloys of that metal.
contains.11: 7. Classification of composite articles:

12.text: Except where the headings other wise require, articles of base metal (including articles of mixed materials treated as articles of base metal under the Interpretative Rules) containing two or more base metals are to be treated as articles of the base metal predominating by weight over each of the other metals. For this purpose:

contains.0: (a) Iron and steel, or different kinds of iron or steel, are regarded as one and the same metal;
contains.1: (b) An alloy is regarded as being entirely composed of that metal as an alloy of which, by virtue of Note 5, it is classified; and
contains.2: (c) A cermet of heading 8113 is regarded as a single base metal.

13.text: 8. In this Section, the following expressions have the meanings hereby assigned to them:

contains.1: metal waste and scrap from the manufacture or mechanical working of metals, and metal goods definitely not usable as such because of breakage, cutting-up, wear or other reasons.
contains.2: (b) Powders:

14.text: products of which 90% or more by weight passes through a sieve having a mesh aperture of 1 mm.

1.text: Iron and Steel

15.text: 1. In this Chapter and, in the case of Notes (d), (e) and (f) throughout this Schedule, the following expressions have the meanings hereby assigned to them:

1.text: Iron-carbon alloys not usefully malleable, containing more than 2% by weight of carbon and which may contain by weight one or more other elements within the following limits:

contains.2: - not more than 3% of phosphorus
contains.3: - not more than 8% of silicon
contains.4: - a total of not more than 10% of other elements.

contains.2: (b) Spiegeleisen:
contains.3: Iron-carbon alloys containing by weight more than 6% but not more than 30% of manganese and otherwise conforming to the specification at (a) above.
contains.4: (c) Ferro-alloys:

5.text: Alloys in pigs, blocks, lumps or similar primary forms, in forms obtained by continuous casting and also in granular or powder forms, whether or not agglomerated, commonly used as an additive in the manufacture of other alloys or as de-oxidants, de-sulphurising agents or for similar uses in ferrous metallurgy and generally not usefully malleable, containing by weight 4% or more of the element iron and one or more of the following:

contains.2: - more than 3% of phosphorus
contains.3: - more than 8% of silicon
contains.4: - a total of more than 10% of other elements, excluding carbon, subject to a maximum content of 10% in the case of copper.

contains.7: Ferrous materials other than those of heading 7203 which (with the exception of certain types produced in the form of castings) are usefully malleable and which contain by weight 2% or less of carbon. However, chromium steels may contain higher proportions of carbon.

8.text: (e) Stainless steel:

contains.9: Alloy steels containing, by weight, 1.2% or less of carbon and 10.5% or more of chromium, with or without other elements.
contains.10: (f) Other alloy steel:

11.text: Steels not complying with the definition of stainless steel and containing by weight one or more of the following elements in the proportion shown:

contains.2: - 0.3% or more of chromium
contains.3: - 0.3% or more of cobalt
contains.4: - 0.4% or more of copper
contains.5: - 0.4% or more of lead
contains.7: - 0.08% or more of molybdenum
contains.8: - 0.3% or more of nickel

contains.12: - 0.06% or more of niobium
contains.15: - 0.3% or more of tungsten (wolfram)
contains.18: - 0.1% or more of other elements (except sulphur, phosphorus, carbon and nitrogen), taken separately.
contains.19: (g) Remelting scrap ingots of iron and steel:
contains.20: Products roughly cast in the form of ingots without feeder-heads or hot tops, or of pigs, having obvious surface faults and not complying with the chemical composition of pig iron, spiegeleisen or ferro-alloys.
contains.22: Products of which less than 90% by weight passes through a sieve with a mesh aperture of 1 mm and of which 90% or more by weight passes through a sieve with a mesh aperture of 5 mm.
contains.24: Continuous cast products of solid section, whether or not subjected to primary hot-rolling; and other products of solid section, which have not been further worked than subjected to primary hot-rolling or roughly shaped by forging, including blanks for angles, shapes or sections.

25.text: These products are not presented in coils.

27.text: Rolled products of solid rectangular (other than square) cross-section, which do not conform to the definition at (ij) above in the form of:

contains.0: - coils of successively superimposed layers, or
contains.1: - straight lengths, which is of a thickness less than 4.75 mm are of a width measuring at least ten times the thickness or if of a thickness of 4.75 mm or more are of a width which exceeds 150 mm and measures at least twice the thickness.

contains.28: Flat-rolled products include those with patterns in relief derived directly from rolling (for example, grooves, ribs, chequers, tears, buttons, lozenges) and those which have been perforated, corrugated or polished, provided that they do not thereby assume the character of articles or products of other headings.
contains.29: Flat-rolled products of a shape other than rectangular or square, of any size, are to be classified as products of a width of 600 mm or more, provided that they do not assume the character of articles or products of other headings.
contains.30: (l) Bars and rods, hot-rolled, in irregularly wound coils: Hot-rolled products in irregularly wound coils, which have a solid cross-section in the shape of circles, segments of circles, ovals, rectangles (including squares), triangles or other convex polygons (including “flattened circles” and “modified rectangles”, of which two opposite sides are convex arcs, the other two sides being straight, of equal length and parallel). These products may have indentations, ribs, grooves or other deformations produced during the rolling process (reinforcing bars and rods).

31.text: (m) Other bars and rods: Products which do not conform to any of the definitions at (ij), (k) or (l) above or to the definition of wire, which have a uniform solid cross-section along their whole length in the shape of circles, segments of circles, ovals, rectangles (including squares), triangles or other convex polygons (including “flattened circles” and “modified rectangles”, of which two opposite sides are convex arcs, the other two sides being straight, of equal length and parallel). These products may:

contains.0: - have indentations, ribs, grooves or other deformations produced during the rolling process (reinforcing bars and rods);

contains.32: (n) Angles, shapes and sections: Products having a uniform solid cross-section along their whole length which do not conform to any of the definitions at (ij), (k), (l) or (m) above or to the definition of wire. Chapter 72 does not include products of heading 7301 or 7302.

33.text: (o) Wire: Cold-formed products in coils, of any uniform solid cross-section along their whole length, which do not conform to the definition of flat-rolled products.

contains.34: (p) Hollow drill bars and rods: Hollow bars and rods of any cross-section, suitable for drills, of which the greatest external dimension of the cross-section exceeds 15 mm but does not exceed 52 mm, and of which the greatest internal dimension does not exceed one half of the greatest external dimension. Hollow bars and rods of iron or steel not conforming to this definition are to be classified in heading 7304.

contains.16: 2. Ferrous metals clad with another ferrous metal are to be classified as products of the ferrous metal predominating by weight.

17.text: 3. Iron or steel products obtained by electrolytic deposition, by pressure casting or by sintering are to be classified, according to their form, their composition and their appearance, in the headings of this Chapter appropriate to similar hot-rolled products.

contains.18: 1. In this Chapter the following expressions have the meaning hereby assigned to them:
contains.19: (a) Alloy pig iron: Pig iron containing by weight one or more of the following elements in the specified proportions: - more than 0.2% of chromium - more than 0.3% of copper - more than 0.3% of nickel - more than 0.1% of any of the following elements: aluminium, molybdenum, titanium, tungsten (wolfram), vanadium.
contains.20: (b) Non-alloy free-cutting steel: Non-alloy steel containing, by weight, one or more of the following elements in the specified proportions: - 0.08% or more of Sulphur - 0.1% or more of lead - more than 0.05% of selenium - more than 0.01% of tellurium - more than 0.05% of bismuth
contains.21: (c) Silicon-electrical steel: Alloy steels containing by weight at least 0.6% but not more than 6% of silicon and not more than 0.08% of carbon. They may also contain by weight not more than 1% of aluminium but no other element in a proportion that would give the steel the characteristics of another alloy steel.
contains.22: (d) High speed steel: Alloy steels containing, with or without other elements, at least two of the three elements molybdenum, tungsten and vanadium with a combined content by weight of 7% or more, 0.6% or more of carbon and 3 to 6% of chromium.

23.text: (e) Silico-manganese steel: Alloy steels containing by weight: - not more than 0.7% of carbon, - 0.5% or more but not more than 1.9% of manganese, and - 0.6% or more but not more than 2.3% of silicon, but no other element in a proportion that would give the steel the characteristics of another alloy steel.

contains.24: 2. For the classification of ferro-alloys in the sub-headings of heading 72.02 the following rule should be observed:
contains.25: A ferro-alloy is considered as binary and classified under the relevant sub-heading (if it exists) if only one of the alloy elements exceeds the minimum percentage laid down in Chapter Note 1(c); by analogy, it is considered respectively as ternary or quaternary if two or three alloy elements exceed the minimum percentage.

26.text: For the application of this rule the unspecified “other elements” referred to in Chapter Note 1(c) must each exceed 10% by weight.

contains.27: 1. Skelp means hot-rolled narrow strip of width not exceeding 600 mm with rolled (square, slightly round or bevelled) edge.
contains.28: 2. Ferrous metals clad with another ferrous metal are to be classified as products of the ferrous metal predominating by weight.
contains.29: 3. Iron or steel products obtained by electrolytic deposition, by pressure casting by sintering are to be classified, according to their form, their composition and their appearance, in the headings of this Chapter appropriate to similar hot-rolled products.
